required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Differences in Efficacy Between Nasal and Oronasal Masks in the Treatment of Obstructive Sleep Apnea With Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP)
clinical_study.official_title: Differences in Efficacy Between Nasal and Oronasal Masks in the Treatment of Obstructive Sleep Apnea With Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP): A Randomized Cross-over Study

lead_sponsor.agency: Weill Medical College of Cornell University

clinical_study.source: Weill Medical College of Cornell University

oversight_info.authority: Weill Cornell Institutional Review Board, USA:

brief_summary.textblock: Our group previously conducted a study looking at the performance of three styles of positive airway pressure masks during laboratory treatment studies for obstructive sleep apnea, and we found that patients using a full-mask mask required higher positive airway pressures than patients using nasal or nasal pillows style masks to achieve successful reduction of respiratory events. In the current study we want to randomly assign patients to either nasal or full-face masks and then switch to a different mask (if nasal was originally chosen than the mask will be switched to full-face and vise versa) after 3-weeks of use to see if the number of respiratory events change with the different mask style. We expect the number of respiratory events will increase with the use of full-face masks.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Crossover Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Treatment

primary_outcome.measure: Comparison of the effectiveness of nasal versus oronasal CPAP masks
primary_outcome.description: Measure the difference in residual apnea/ hypopnea index (AHI) between the oronasal and nasal masks during CPAP treatment. A total of 14 subjects have completed the protocol.

arm_group.description: Initial administration of oronasal CPAP mask
Initial administration of nasal CPAP mask

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 18 years or older
- previously diagnosed with OSA
- returning for PAP titrations at the Center for Sleep Medicine
- CPAP and titration naive
- Must have a Apnea/Hypopnea Index (AHI) of ≥ 16/hr.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients with ≥ 50% central apneas

facility.name: Weill Cornell Center for Sleep Medicine
